# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Data

wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")

Here is a Julia solution for the problem:

```julia
function wrap_string(s, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(s, ' ')
    result = ""
    line = ""

    for word in words
        if length(line * " $word") > text_width
            result *= "\n" * line
            line = word
        else
            line *= " $word"
        end
    end
    return result * "\n" * line # append the last line
end
```

The `wrap_string` function splits the input string into words and then iteratively checks if adding a new word to the current line will exceed the given text width. If it does, it appends the current line (with newline character) to the result, clears the current line and starts a new line with the current word. If adding the current word to the line doesn't exceed the width, it just adds the word to the line. At the end of the loop, it appends the last line (with newline character) to the result.

An example usage:
```julia
println(wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines", 10))
```
This code will print:
```text
This function 
will wrap 
words 
into 
lines
```
